5.00.text: And so Marc Andreessen has some great quotes,

7.63.text: and I'll refer you to a blog that he wrote in a second.

11.27.text: "In a great market, a market with lots of real potential customers,

15.23.text: the market pulls product out of the startup.

21.01.text: you can have the best product in the world,

28.02.text: The number one company killer is a lack of market."

31.91.text: Andy Radcliffe has another way of saying it.

35.06.text: When a great team meets a lousy market, the market wins.

42.16.text: When a mediocre team meets a great market, the market often wins.

48.50.text: Have you ever seen a startup where you're like,

50.15.text: how in the hell could they have been successful?

53.06.text: It's because they met a great market.

55.21.text: And sometimes, your product, your market, it just has the magic.

59.85.text: You can't beat customers off with a stick.

63.63.text: I've had this happen to me before,

65.48.text: where in spite of the fact that the product

67.89.text: just seemed horrible on the surface,

74.05.text: I'll give you an example of this where the market was really good.

78.63.text: At Chegg, we decided we wanted to do textbook rentals.

80.86.text: It was one of our early investments.

82.90.text: Does anybody ever use Chegg at Stanford?

86.02.text: So we're like, OK are textbook rentals going to work?

89.79.text: We don't even have a warehouse.

91.75.text: And so we're just like, OK what we do?

94.16.text: So somebody would rent a textbook from Chegg,

98.90.text: And they'd call us up and say, what's up with this?

101.94.text: I thought I'm renting a textbook from

103.31.text: Chegg and you shipped it from Amazon.

105.95.text: And we'd say, oh it's just a clerical supply chain error.

109.57.text: Would you please ship it back to Chegg?

114.14.text: But people put up with it,

115.57.text: because they just loved the idea of renting a textbook.

117.79.text: They're like, let me get this straight.

119.56.text: Textbook costs me $100, you'll rent it to me for $35.

123.54.text: And so they just kept renting them no matter

125.69.text: how disorganized we seemed in the early days.

131.23.text: So to me, product market fit is more of like

134.79.text: a dance between the product and the market.

137.28.text: You know it's like if you ever see two people doing the tango,

140.76.text: I look at it like the product is leading the dance,

143.59.text: but the market is tangoing with the product.

147.84.text: I'll try to be G-rated in my language,

149.65.text: but sort of an intimate sort of back and forth between them.

153.57.text: And what I find is that if you want to get the tango right,

156.71.text: the first thing is to really identify the market.

160.91.text: Large, strong customer desire and the right time.

165.84.text: You want to find markets where people gravitate

169.39.text: to your idea and want it right now, as soon as possible,

176.56.text: And then that market pulls the product.

181.72.text: When a market pulls a product,

183.01.text: this is what it feels like inside the building.

185.19.text: Nobody's debating what the features of the next version ought to be,

188.49.text: because they're like, oh my god.

190.21.text: This stuff is flying off the shelves,

192.38.text: and our customer needs us to fix x, y, and z. And you're like,

197.51.text: And so that's what it feels like when

201.26.text: Whereas where the market's not pulling the product,

204.06.text: the conversations in the building are arguments over,

207.31.text: why aren't those customers smart enough

208.99.text: to figure out how awesome our stuff is?

211.23.text: And back and forth, and is my vision more right than

215.52.text: your vision about what the product ought to be?

218.74.text: And then the last part of it is delighting

222.02.text: the customer in the other direction.

223.36.text: So you know, the part of the dance where the

225.64.text: customer follows is they're pulling product.

228.96.text: And where you lead is you assimilate that information all the time,

235.94.text: So by the way, the first thing that I see-- we talked

238.34.text: about this-- not doing the dance is the first mistake

242.02.text: I see in people not achieving product market fit.

245.38.text: And conversely, the people who do this

246.71.text: well often get to there faster.

249.58.text: The second thing is not clearing the threshold of delight.

254.19.text: So a lot of people think their product is good and that

256.96.text: rational customers ought to like it and buy it.

260.05.text: But customers-- I won't use the exact words-- they need to say, WTF.

264.59.text: I didn't know that that was even possible.

267.56.text: So I'll give you an example.

268.81.text: When Lyft first launched, we had an associate at the time.

272.34.text: He's now at Rothenberg Ventures, Tommy Leep.

274.83.text: And he was the Stanford treat,

277.07.text: for those of you who've been here for a while.

282.54.text: Well, Lyft launched Lyft, and we're like, I hope it goes well.

287.67.text: Tommy comes into the team meeting and says,

291.55.text: we're going to crush it in this deal.

297.41.text: He's like, I've used it 10 times in the last week.

299.93.text: He's like, have you tried it yet?

301.58.text: We're like, well I'm going to get around to it.

303.09.text: I haven't been to San Francisco, but I'll check it out.

306.12.text: He's like, dude it just, it rocks.

308.96.text: You just get out your phone, there's a car on the map,

312.15.text: you ask for a car, and it picks you up.

314.69.text: And keep in mind, this is before Uber decided to react to Lyft

317.90.text: with Uber X. Like nobody had ever had a service before where just

321.66.text: some stranger in a car pulls up when you request the ride,

325.74.text: and takes you where you want to go.

327.65.text: And keep in mind at the time,

329.19.text: the cabs in San Francisco were horrible.

330.94.text: So you'd never get a cab in San Francisco.

334.31.text: And so it was one of these experiences where

336.47.text: I remember the first time I tried it,

338.70.text: it was obvious to me that this product

341.06.text: was going to be a huge success.

342.19.text: There was just no doubt in my mind.
